history.content: Have you looked into a pure stochastic processes class OP? In particular, I'm talking about IEOR 173 and Stat 150

children.subject: Haven't looked much into those two classes yet. I've just heard really good things about 126's usefulness. Would you say Stat 150 or IEOR 173 are more similar to 126, or could it still be useful to take 126 in the future? I glanced over the syllabus and curriculum for 126, and I find the labs particularly interesting, which is why I am considering it, but I'd ideally not want to re-learn the same content.
Thank you for the advice. It does seem that content covered in 126 is more in-depth and practical after further research, so its probably a good choice to take it at some point.

I havent taken 140, but im in 126 and use teh 140 textbook from time to time to learn about some of the stuff in this class. 126 is more of a survey course into applications of probability, like markov chains, poisson processes, kalman filters, etc.. 
I think its a good idea to take 126, and you'll be familiar with a lot of probability already so you should be able to relax into the course nicely. I think that there is a bit of overlap, but the second halves of both courses are pretty different in focus (glancing at the 140 schedule). So there's no harm in taking both, and you'll definitely learn something valuable out of 126 after taking 140. In fact I think since your more seasoned with probability knowledge, you'll probably get more out of it than most.

history.content: So I know questions about 126 and 140 have been asked a lot, but I wanted to know more about the overlap between the courses. I am taking 140 and 70 this semester, and I really enjoy the way the content is covered in 140. I'm a CS major (taking some classes in DS and Stats), so I was also thinking of taking 126 later. How much different / overlapped content is there between the two classes, and do you think it would be worthwhile to have taken both?
history.subject: EECS 126 after Prob 140
